attributes.title: Repetition effects in letters and digits: Evidence from same-different matching
attributes.description: According to open-bigram theory (Grainger & van Heuven, 2004), letter repetitions should be harder to detect in different responses (e.g., KGLBS – KGLGS) compared with the insertion condition (e.g., KGLBS – KGLTS) because there are more incompatible bigrams in the insert condition. On the contrary, same responses to letter stimuli with repetitions (e.g., KGLGS – KGLGS) should be easier to make than same responses to stimuli without repetitions (e.g., KGLTS – KGLTS), because there are fewer bigrams to match in the former. Crucially, open-bigram theory predicts that these effects should be greater for letter stimuli compared with digit stimuli.

question.value:
A same-different matching paradigm was used with the presentation of a reference sequence followed by a target sequence, and participants have to decide if the two were identical or not. The reference sequences were forty 5-consonant base-sequences from 9 letters: G, N, D, K, F, T, S, B, and L, and forty 5-digit sequences from digits 1 – 9.  We used 9 letters in order to match the number of different digits used in the digit version of the experiment. We first constructed random sequences of each type of stimulus with no repetition. From these reference sequences, we constructed 2 types of different target sequence by replacing one of the internal letters / digits of the reference with a different letter that could either be a letter/digit already present in the reference sequence (repetition condition) or a letter/digit not present in the reference sequence (insertion). In the same response condition, the different targets of the different response condition became reference and target, and therefore either had a letter/digit repetition or not.

Table 1. Examples of the different experimental conditions for letter stimuli.
Reference	Target 	condition
KGLBS	KGLGS	diff / rep
KGLBS	KGLTS	diff / ins
KGLGS    KGLGS	 same / rep
KGLTS	KGLTS	 same / norep

Note. diff: different response / same: same response; ins: insertion; rep: repetition. 


Procedure
We first informed participants that the data will be collected anonymously and then we asked participant to choose between 9 languages (French, English, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Chinese, German, Dutch, and Arabic) in order to present the instructions in their native language. Then, we asked the participant to select a gender and a range of age. Experiment follows presenting the instructions on the screen. After running 8 practice trials, the experiment begins. Preceded by a countdown of 3 seconds, the first trial starts with the presentation of the reference 32 pixels above the center of the screen for 300 ms. After a quick gap of 100 ms, we presented the target 32 pixels below the center of the screen until the keyboard input. Participants were instructed to give their responses using right and left arrows, as fast and as accurately as possible. A short feedback dot (500 ms) was presented, in green if the response was correct or in red otherwise.
Figure 1 represents an example of one trial.

The experiment was created using OpenSesame (version 2.3.8) and converted to online experiment using OSWeb (version 1.3.3). We then upload this online experiment into JATOS Server that saving the data. 

We will recruit online data from volunteer French native speaker in the range 18-29 years old. They will be informed that data will be collected anonymously prior the beginning of the experiment. A power analysis (Green & MacLeod, 2016) indicated that with 125 participants we could have 80 % power.

q11.value: We constructed 40 base-sequences that we split in 4 conditions among a Latin-Square design.

q12.value:
According to Brusbaert & Stevens (2018), a population around 160 participants is nedded.

Following Green & McLeod (2016), an estimation of 125 participants allow us to reach 80% of experimental power.

hypothesis.value:
We are studying reactions to the outbreak of COVID-19. We have already collected a first wave of data. There are a number of hypotheses that we will test. 

The greater anxiety people feel, the more time they spend thinking about/consuming information relating to coronavirus, the lower their well-being. We expect this relationship to differ as a function of ideology- for people high on RWA, the toll of coronavirus will have less of a negative impact on well-being (particularly meaning in life). We also expect people high on RWA, conservatism, and Trump support will be less anxious about coronavirus, find the actions taken (e.g., closing schools/businesses) to be more of an overreaction, and to take fewer health precautions (e.g., hand-washing, social distancing, etc). People high on RWA, conservatism, and Trump support will also favor coronavirus information coming from Trump and Fox News, rather than other news outlets, the CDC, and science. These groups of people will also show enhanced prejudice towards minoritized outgroups associated with coronavirus, including people who are Asian, and immigrants, but not towards non-minoritized outgroups, such as Italians. This relationship will be especially strong among those high on RWA who are experiencing especially negative reactions to coronavirus (higher threat including anxiety, worry, and uncertainty). 

We also expect to observe within person and normative changes in RWA and well-being over time. As the threat of coronavirus grows larger, people should increase on RWA, and their relative preference for security over freedom. We also expect to observe such increases on ethnocentrism, negative attitudes towards immigration, and prejudice. Generally speaking, meaning in life will also decrease over time. However, we expect this decrease to be weaker among people higher on RWA. We will also test whether changes in MIL precede or result from changes in RWA. Both possibilities are conceptually plausible. 

We expect for all of the above predictions about RWA and MIL, that the significance facet of meaning in life will be more relevant than the purpose or coherence facets. 

We will also examine how reactions to coronavirus have changed as a function of Trump support. Previously, Trump downplayed the severity of the pandemic, and conservatives were taking health precautions less seriously. Trump has now changed his tune, and we will test whether this change relates to Trump supporters, conservatives, and people high on RWA feeling more anxious, worried, uncertain, threatened, taking better health precautions, and expressing less prejudice.

attributes.title: AD Biomarkers and prognosis of subjective cognitive decline
attributes.description:
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common reason for dementia. Pathophysiologically it is based on neurodegeneration, which is associated with brain amyloid ß (Aß) deposition and neurofibrillary tangle (NFT) burden. Both processes are known to begin years before the first symptoms of cognitive decline.The stage of subjective cognitive decline (SCD) is a preclinical stage of AD and describes a condition where healthy adults are concerned about a cognitive decline, while performance on neuropsychological testing is within normal limits and activities of daily living are preserved. Individuals with SCD with a biomarker-based evidence of AD are at higher risk for developing cognitive decline.

Within this systematic review and metaanalysis we want to investigate the estimated clinical progression rate to dementia in individuals with subjective cognitive decline with regard to their biomarker profile for Alzheimer's disease. 

Method:
This systematic review employs a four-step search strategy. 1) First, search terms and search strings are developed and pretested in PubMed. Search strings are three-parted with one section referring to subjective cognitive decline, another to the biomarkers for Alzheimer's disease and a third fraction consisting of the clinical stages of Alzheimer's disease. All parts will be combined using the Boolean Operator “AND”. 2) After the pretest, key publications will be identified and analyzed for wording used in title and abstract as well as index terms. This step
aims at expanding and adapting search terms to cover additional and divergent wording. 3) After search terms and search strings are finalized for PubMed, the search strategy will be adapted to each of the additional databases and
the actual search will be conducted in the following databases: 1. PubMed 2. Cochrane Library 3. PsycINFO. The reference list of all publications included in the review will be hand searched for additional studies that meet the following inclusion criteria: To be included in this review articles must be published in a peer-reviewed journal and written in English with full-text available. No time filters will be employed. Studies must include the detection of biomarkers for AD in CSF or by means of neuroimaging, such as Amyloid- and/or Tau-PET-CT. Articles will be screened by title and abstract for eligibility by two independent reviewers using the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Any discrepancies will be resolved through discussion and when necessary through review by a third reviewer. If eligibility is unclear, full text review will be undertaken of studies deemed potential eligible by title/abstract screening. Articles selected for full-text review will then be reviewed employing the same standard. Excluded articles will be coded for reason of exclusion. Data synthesis will be assisted by an evaluation matrix developed for the purpose of this review. Categories and codes will be predefined based on the research question and will be further developed during the data extraction process.The quality of included studies will be evaluated independently by two reviewers using a standardized set of criteria such as the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for randomized studies and ROBIN-I for non-randomized studies.

attributes.title: Selfish genes or selfish memes - Study 3 (Replication of Study 2)
attributes.description: A direct replication of Study 2 which will be conducted during the COVID-19 outbreak in Serbia.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Selfish genes or selfish memes - Study 3 (Replication of Study 2)

other.value:
Three questions at the end of the survey will ask participants about how worried they are about getting seriously ill from COVID-19, about someone in their family getting seriously ill from COVID-19, and about how much the COVID-19 outbreak affects their daily lives.

We will test the psychometric properties (i.e., distribution, reliability, item difficulty) of the willingness to help scale. We will repeat the main analyses within each of the levels of the cost of helping (low-cost, medium-cost, high-cost).

The following sociodemographic variables will be assessed: participant sex, participant age, and highest educational attainment.

sample.value:
After controlling for the effect of participant sex, the age of the target individual, the age difference between the participant and the target individual, and residential distance, Study 2 (N = 762) revealed a significant effect of genetic relatedness of Eta Squared = 0.063 and a significant effect of memetic similarity of Eta Squared = 0.132.

We conducted an a priori two-way ANOVA power analysis for the 3 x 3 between-subject design using the software environment R and the package easypower. Assuming α = .05, N = 239 would suffice to detect an effect of Eta Squared = 0.063, with 95% power.

The online survey will accept responses until there is n = 27 in each of the nine groups.

analyses.value:
To test H1a and H2a we will perform an ANOVA using two between-subjects factors: 
a) ‘genetic relatedness’ (r = 0.5, r = 0.125, and r = 0), and 
b) ’perceived similarity’ (very similar, somewhat similar, not similar). 

’Perceived similarity’ of important attitudes and values with the target individual will be rated on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 0 = not at all similar to 6 = completely similar, and later transformed into three levels (0-2 will be recoded as not similar, 3-4 as somewhat similar, 5-6 as very similar). 

To test H1b and H2b, we will additionally perform pairwise comparisons between the three ‘genetic relatedness’ levels and the three ’perceived similarity’ levels. The post-hoc Bonferroni tests adjust for multiple comparisons.

We will repeat all of the above analyses while controlling for: 
a) sex of the participant,
b) the age of the target individual, 
c) the age difference between the participant and the target individual, 
d) residential distance in kilometers (transformed into a base-10 logarithmic value), 
e) frequency of contact (the means of interaction include face-to-face communication, telephone calls, email, and text messages; the frequency categories are never, once per year or less, twice or more times per year, once per month, once per week, twice or more times per week, daily), 
f) perceived frequency of future contact (scale ranging from 0 = never to 6 = very often), 
g) perceived probability of future contact (scale ranging from 0 = not at all likely to 6 = highly likely), and
h) emotional closeness with the target individual (scale ranging from 0 = not at all close to 6 = completely close).

Covariates a) through d) will be considered together; and, in a separate model, covariates e) through h) will be considered together.

outliers.value:
Following exclusion criteria will be applied:
a) incorrectly answering both of the 2 attention check questions,
b) incorrect assignment to an experimental condition due to technical difficulties with the “finding the target individual” questionnaire (i.e., answering “yes” to having more than one category of individual in one’s social network or answering “no” to having any of the categories of individual),
c) reporting that their sibling is adopted (r = 0) or that they are half-siblings (r = 0.25) or monozygotic twins (r = 1), and
d) reporting that their uncle/aunt is not the biological parent of their cousin (r = 0) or that their cousin is adopted (r = 0).

Inclusion criteria: 
a) being aged 18 or above (as screened in the survey), and
b) living in Serbia (as screened by the online participant recruiting service).

dependent.value:
Willingness to help rated on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 0 = not at all ready to 6 = completely ready. Two items assess low-cost help (emotional support and the granting of small favors); four items assess medium-cost help (help with everyday living, help during an illness, help with housing, and financial help); two high-cost items ask participants about their willingness to help in hypothetical life-or-death situations (rescuing someone from a burning building and donating a kidney). This scale is adapted from Stewart-Williams (2008).

References:
Stewart-Williams, S. (2008). Human Beings as Evolved Nepotists. Human Nature, 19(4), 414–425. doi:10.1007/s12110-008-9048-y

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to one of six conditions, each of which involves answering questions about one individual in the participant’s social network. It will be specified that the target individual has to be of the same sex as the participant.

The conditions are defined by: 
a) the relationship of the target individual to the participant (‘genes’): full sibling (coefficient of relatedness (r) = 0.5), cousin (r = 0.125) or unrelated acquaintance/friend (i.e., nonkin, r = 0), and
b) shared similarity of important attitudes and values with the target individual (‘memes’): similar or not similar.

hypothesis.value:
H1a: Genetic relatedness will affect willingness to help. H1b: With higher levels of genetic relatedness, willingness to help will increase – people will be more willing to help cousins than nonkin, and more willing to help siblings than cousins.

H2a: Memetic similarity will affect willingness to help. H2b: With higher levels of memetic similarity, willingness to help will increase – people will be more willing to help those who are somewhat similar to them than those who are not similar, and more willing to help individuals who are very similar to them than individuals who are somewhat similar.

attributes.title: Misperceived Social Norms Drive Noncompliance with COVID-19 Preventative Behaviors
attributes.description: Research examining whether underestimating the strength/impact of social norms related to COVID-19 preventative behaviors is associated with a decreased intention to engage in such behaviors.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Study 1: Misperceived Social Norms Drive Noncompliance with COVID-19 Preventative Behaviors

other.value: This study is the first is a series of studies hoping to examine these dynamics cross-culturally, and potentially develop interventions which target participants' perceptions of social norms to increase behavioral intentions. As such, in addition to the analyses above, we plan to conduct exploratory analyses in order to inform future iteration of this specific study, along with continuations of this project overall. Expected exploratory analyses include examining whether the analyses above are moderated by demographic variables, variables related to COVID-19 exposure, trust in government, and whether hypothesis 1a is robust to matching the perceived norm measure to “true-population values” derived from weighting responses to the belief measured such that they are representative of the US population.

sample.value:
We aim to collect a total of 300 responses via the Prolific survey platform. Participants must be residents of the United States (per Prolific’s prescreen questions) and much have a 95% approval rating. N = 300 was determined via power analysis and financial constraints. 

To examine statistical power we considered our RSA analysis, which examines behavioral intentions across five repeated measures compared to the ten repeated measures in our analyses of mean differences in beliefs and perceived norms. As such, the power for our RSA analysis is the most conservative measure of power. If we assume a 15% attrition rate (final N = 255) and a low correlation (r = 0.2) between our repeated measures, we are powered at 90% to detect a small effect size (f = 0.10) in a repeated-measures ANOVA framework. Given that we anticipate the true correlations among participant’s intentions to engage in preventive behaviors to be much higher, we argue that we are highly power to detect any scientifically meaningful effect sizes in our current design. 

Upon completion of data collection we will conduct post-hoc power analyses and use those effect size estimates as the bases for power analyses in future iterations of this study.

analyses.value:
All analyses will be conducted across all behavioral items and the importance/impact measures, which are treated as repeated measures using linear mixed-effects modeling. 

Hypothesis 1a will be examined by analyzing mean differences between the belief items and perceived social norms items in a mixed-effects regression model. Due to repeated measures we will include random intercept for participants in the regression. Belief and perceived norm items will be centered at the scale midpoint (50, scales are 0-100, so centered scale will be -50 to 50), and as such the intercept estimate in the regression will serve as a test of mean differences. Below is the equation representing the analysis for H1a (parenthetical represents random intercepts). 

Perceived Norms ~ Beliefs + (1|Participant)

Hypothesis 1b will be examined by entering mean-centered political orientation and mean-centered reactance as separate interactions with beliefs in predicting perceived norms via the model used to test H1a. Each interaction will be tested in separate models. For each model we will compute marginal intercept means and marginal slope means, which will be reported with estimates and 95% confidence intervals only (i.e., no p-values). To test hypothesis 1b we will conduct post-hoc a test examining whether the intercept estimates at +/- 1 SD of each moderator significantly differs from the intercept estimate at the mean. P-values for these contrasts will be adjusted for the false-discovery rate via Benjamini & Hochberg (1995). As the model’s intercept estimate is a test of mean differences between beliefs and perceived norms, significant deviation from that estimate at +/- 1 SD of the moderate would constitute evidence for our hypothesis.  

Perceived Norms ~ Beliefs + Political Orientation + Beliefs x Political Orientation + (1|Participant)

Perceived Norms ~ Beliefs + Reactance + Beliefs x Reactance + (1|Participant)

Hypothesis 1c will examine whether the analysis above is moderated by behavior and measure, separately. Behavior/measure will be entered as categorical fixed-effects and interacted with beliefs in predicting perceived norms. From this analysis we will compute least-squared means by behavior and measure to examine intercept estimates within each category, where we will report estimates and 95% confidence intervals only (i.e., no p-values). To test hypothesis 1c we will examine post-hoc pairwise comparisons of marginal means across behaviors/measures, with p-values adjusted for the false-discovery rate via Benjamini & Hochberg (1995).

Perceived Norms ~ Beliefs x [Behavior/Measure] Category + (1|Participant)

Hypothesis 2 will be examined using linear mixed effect modeling. Behavioral intentions will be regressed onto fixed effects for beliefs and perceived norms and a random effect for participants. 

Intentions ~ Beliefs + Perceived Norms + (1|Participant)

Hypothesis 3 will examine whether the difference between belief and perceived norms uniquely predicts intentions using response surface analysis (RSA), a polynomial regression technique for examining how differences in two measures predict a third. RSA involves regressing the DV (Intentions) onto fixed effects for beliefs and perceived norms, the interaction between beliefs and perceived norms, and the squared values of beliefs and perceived norms. We will follow the procedure outlined by Barranti, Carlson, & Côté (2017), where a main effects only model (from hypothesis 2) is compared to the full model described above. If the full model significantly improves model fit (measured through a likelihood-ratio test) and at least one of the polynomial predictors is statistically significant, then we will proceed with plotting the response-surface and corresponding slopes. We will control for participant-effects (due to repeated-measures) by including random intercepts for participants into the analysis. 

Intentions = Beliefs + Perceived Norms + Beliefs x Perceived Norms + Beliefs^2 + Perceived Norms^2 + (1|Participant)

outliers.value:
The survey includes an attention check where participants must write out in english the answer to a simple math problem (see survey language). Failing the check does not preclude participants from completing the survey or getting paid. However, all responses from all participants who fail the attention check will be excluded a priori from all analyses. We will also exclude from our analyses all participants who complete the survey in less than 90 seconds, as the anticipated length of the survey is 5 minutes and completion in less than 90 seconds likely represents participants not meaningfully/attentively responding to questions. 

We will utilize pairwise deletion of data throughout our analyses.

dependent.value:
We are examining the relationship between three primary variables of interest related to a series of preventative COVID-19 behaviors (see below). Those variables are (1) individuals’ own perceptions of those behaviors (“Beliefs”), (2) individuals’ forecasts of others’ perceptions of those behaviors (“Perceived Social Norms”), and (3) individuals’ intentions to engage in those behaviors (“Behavioral Intentions”). Beliefs and perceived norms are measured at the level of “importance” and “impact” of a given behavior, and we treat responses across these measures as repeated measures. We control for repeated measures by utilizing linear mixed effects regression and modeling participant level random intercepts. 

Beliefs, perceived norms, and behavioral intentions are measured across five different preventative health behaviors: Leaving your home only for essentials; Avoiding face-to-face interactions with friends; Engaging in physical contact with no one other than those you live with; Self-quarantining if feeling sick for a minimum of 14 days; Regular hand washing for 20 seconds. 

All measures across all behaviors are captured cross-sectionally using 0-100 sliding scales on the online Qualtrics survey platform. 

See attached “Survey Language (Study 1)” documents for all measurement specifics.

conditions.value: No conditions. This survey is cross-sectional and correlational, and involves no experimental manipulations.

hypothesis.value:
Our research question relates to (1) the (in)congruence between individuals’ beliefs about COVID-19 prevention behaviors and their forecast of others’ beliefs (i.e., perceived social norms) about such behavior, and (2) whether this incongruence is associated with intentions to engage in those behaviors in the future. All hypotheses will be tested in an American convenience sample. 

Confirmatory Hypothesis 1a predicts a pluralistic ignorance effect of norm-underestimation in participants’ forecast of others’ beliefs (perceived norms). We predict that participants' forecasts of others’ beliefs about the importance and impact of COVID-19 prevention behaviors will be significantly lower than their own beliefs along those dimensions. 

Exploratory Hypothesis 1b predicts that political orientation and reactance will moderate the pluralistic ignorance effect, such that mean difference between participants’ own beliefs and their perceived norms will vary along participants’ levels of self-reported political ideology and reactance. We make no explicit predictions as to the direction of moderation. 

Exploratory Hypothesis 1c predicts that the mean differences between perceived norms and beliefs will be moderated by the specific behaviors and specific measures (importance and impact) being asked about. We make no explicit predictions as to what behavior/measure will exhibit relatively higher or lower levels of pluralistic ignorance. 

Confirmatory Hypothesis 2 predicts that participants’ own beliefs and perceived norms will each independently and positively predict behavioral intentions. 

Exploratory Hypothesis 3 will examine whether the within-participant difference between beliefs and perceived norms is uniquely associated with behavioral intentions. This is exploratory because we make no prediction as to which direction of the beliefs-norms difference will be uniquely associated with behavioral intentions.

attributes.title: Countering COVID-19 misinformation with humor and active inoculation
attributes.description: The purpose of the study is to investigate different messaging strategies (active vs. passive inoculation, humor vs. non-humor) to identify which message strategy is most effective debunking misinformation about COVID-19. Passive inoculation involves explanation of the techniques used in misinformation, while active inoculation also explains misinforming techniques but with the participant actively interacting with the content. For data collection, we will use an online randomized experiment embedded in a Qualtrics survey. We will hire a research firm, Lucid, to recruit a representative sample of the U.S. public.

q1.value: John Cook, Emily Vraga, Sojung Kim

q2.value:
All of the following hypotheses are intended to be confirmatory.

Associations

H1: Political conservatism is positively associated with individualism.

H2: Individualism and political conservatism is negatively associated with COVID-19 knowledge, social distancing knowledge, and social distancing support.

H3: COVID-19 knowledge is positively associated with social distancing support.

Main effects of experimental manipulations

H4: Active inoculation is more effective than passive inoculation in reducing credibility of misinformation.

H5: Humorous inoculation will be more engaging and humorous than non-humorous inoculation, but less credible. 

H6: Active inoculation will be more engaging than passive inoculation.

Mediation and moderation effects

H7: Inoculation of social distancing misinformation increases social distancing knowledge and support partially by reducing the misinformation’s credibility (mediation effect).

H8: Misinformation opposing social distancing is more effective with people with higher levels of individualism.

The following research questions are intended to be exploratory.

RQ1: What is the relationship between demographics and COVID-19 knowledge, social distancing knowledge, and social distancing support/intent?

RQ2: Will misinformation opposing social distancing reduce COVID-19 knowledge, social distancing knowledge, and social distancing support?

RQ3: Does humor differ from non-humor in reducing credibility of misinformation?

RQ4: Are inoculations equally effective across age, political position, and individualism levels?

RQ5: Will any of the different inoculation types have an effect on COVID knowledge/attitudes/behavioral intent?

RQ6: Will any of the different inoculation types have an effect on attitudes about smoking?

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Our experiment is testing different types of inoculation: passive vs. active, and humor vs. non-humor. Participants are recruited via Lucid  to a Qualtrics online survey with experimental manipulations. They will fill out a brief survey (individualism, political leaning & affiliation, perceived threats), followed by a series of inoculation screens, followed by a misinformation article, then a more extensive survey capturing knowledge and attitudes about COVID-19 and social distancing.

In the passive inoculation condition, we explain the fallacy in misinformation (e.g., the participant passively reads the information) while in the active inoculation condition, we instruct the participant to interact with the content - as much as is possible in an online Qualtrics survey, we try to get the participant committing the fallacy themselves.

We're also testing humor vs. non-humor so our experiment features a 2 x 2 design (e.g., passive non-humor, active non-humor, passive humor, active humor) plus a control condition (no inoculation or misinformation) and misinformation-only condition. In total, participants are divided randomly into six groups:
Control group shown an article about the health benefits of sweet potatoes
Misinformation-only group are shown an article about the health benefits of sweet potatoes before a misinformation article arguing against social distancing in response to COVID-19
Passive, non-humor group are shown a non-humorous, passive inoculation before the misinformation article
Passive, humor group are shown a humorous, passive inoculation before the misinformation article
Active, non-humor group are shown a non-humorous, active inoculation before the misinformation article
Active, humor group are shown a humorous, active inoculation before the misinformation article

Lastly, we're testing the "umbrella of protection" found in inoculation research, where inoculating people in one topic conveys resistance in other topics. So our inoculation looks at anti-vaxxers, and how they focus on individual rights while ignoring how failing to vaccinate endangers their community. The misinformation is an article arguing that social distancing mandates infringes on people's individual rights. 

Before the inoculation/misinformation, we ask questions about individualism, political ideology, and political affiliation. After the inoculation/misinformation, we ask a battery of survey items about COVID-19 knowledge, social distancing knowledge, social distancing support, and the credibility of the interventions. We're hoping to gain a better understanding of different types of inoculation to neutralize misinformation - particularly the direct comparison of passive vs. active inoculation.

Measured variables are listed below. A copy of the full survey instrument is attached.
Individualism (8 items measuring individualism vs collectivism)
Political leaning (conservative to liberal)
Political affiliation
Perceived threats to population (e.g., climate change, COVID-19, etc)
Attitudes about smoking (e.g., smoking in public is an individual right)
Evaluation of inoculation message (credibility, accuracy, humor, etc)
Evaluation of misinformation message (credibility, accuracy, humor, etc)
COVID-19 knowledge
Social distancing knowledge
Social distancing support
Rating scientific facts and falsehoods about COVID-19
Concern about COVID-19
Behavioral intentions about COVID-19
Education level: From a multiple choice, participants indicate the highest level of school completed or the highest degree received.
Gender
Age in years
Race/ethnicity

We will explore RQ1 by testing which model (e.g., linear or curvilinear) best capture the relationship between age and COVID-19 knowledge, social distancing knowledge, and social distancing support.

We will explore RQ2 using ANOVA or regression to test whether COVID-19 knowledge, social distancing knowledge, and social distancing support vary between the control group and misinformation-only group.

We will explore RQ3, H4, and H5 using ANOVA or regression to test whether misperception credibility/inoculation credibility varies between the four inoculation groups.

We will explore RQ4 using regression to test whether age, political position, and individualism levels moderate effect of inoculation on misperception credibility.

We will explore RQ5 using ANOVA or regression to test whether COVID-19 knowledge, social distancing knowledge, and social distancing support vary between the inoculation groups.

We will explore RQ6 using ANOVA or regression to test whether smoking attitudes support vary between the inoculation groups.

We will test H1 using linear regression to explore the relationship between political conservatism and individualism.

We will test H2 using linear regression to explore the relationship between individualism/political conservatism and COVID-19 knowledge/social distancing knowledge/social distancing support.

We will test H3 using linear regression to explore the relationship between COVID-19  and social distancing support.

We will test H6 using a simple mediation model to explore whether misinformation credibility mediates changes in social distancing knowledge and support.

We will test H7 using regression to explore whether individualism moderates changes in social distancing knowledge and support in response to misinformation.

q18.value:
The following items will be averaged to create a “COVID-19 knowledge” variable:
COVID-19 can make anyone sick regardless of their age, race, or ethnicity.
You should wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds to protect against COVID-19.
COVID-19 has a higher mortality rate (e.g., kills more people who are infected) than the flu.
Young people are unlikely to die from COVID-19.

The following items will be averaged to create a “Social distancing knowledge” variable:
Social distancing will reduce deaths form COVID-19.
Social distancing reduces the likelihood someone with COVID-19 will infect others.
You can meet with large groups of people while social distancing as long as you are outside.

The following items will be averaged to create a “Social distancing support” variable:
All adults should stay at home as much as possible to avoid spreading COVID-19.
The government is overestimating the consequences of COVID-19 outbreak. (REVERSE)
Individuals should be able to make the decision for themselves whether their activities are worth the risk of infection. (REVERSE)
Social distancing measures should only apply to high-risk populations such as the elderly. (REVERSE)
We need to balance the risks of COVID-19 infection with the harm to the economy. (REVERSE)
Social distancing causes more problems than it solves. (REVERSE)
People should make their own choices about the risks associated with COVID-19. (REVERSE)
The government needs to make people stay home to limit the spread of COVID-19.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the relationship between variables is statistically significant.

attributes.title: Molecular detection of intestinal helminths and protozoa among young children in Dosso Region, Niger
attributes.description: Eukaryotic parasites are significant contributors to childhood illness in Niger. While helminthiases have received national attention through mass deworming efforts, the epidemiology of intestinal protozoa in Niger remains underexamined. This study employed real-time PCR diagnostics to describe the prevalence of two schistosomes, four soil-transmitted helminths, and one protozoan parasite in Boboye Department, Dosso Region. Prevalence was assessed using bulk stool specimens collected from a population-based sample of 86 children residing in 9 communities. Anthropometric measurements were used to calculate child growth z-scores and stool consistency was graded. Helminths were absent from the study population, with the exception of a single Schistosoma haematobium infection (1/86; 1.2%). Giardia duodenalis was the only protozoa present, detected in 65% (56/86) of children. Prevalence of G. duodenalis peaked in 2-year-olds with 88% (15/17) positivity. The population was generally undernourished, though growth indices did not differ significantly between children with and without G. duodenalis infection.

attributes.title: An investigation into the effects of interletter spacing on reading in dyslexic university students.
attributes.description: By investigating eye-movements during sentence reading, this project aims to investigate the effects of interletter spacing on reading in dyslexic university students, and whether this effect is moderated by word length.
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Unable to complete study due to COVID-19.

attributes.title: moral licensing - disability
attributes.description: Testing the hypothesis that if people are told they score higher than average on a measure of attitudes toward people with disability in an interpersonal domain, they will have have more discriminatory (or less positive) attitudes toward disability in the workplace -- thus, moral licensing may be factor in workplace discrimination of people with disabilities.

q2.value: If people believe they have positive public perceptions of people with disabilities they will feel they have a moral license to have more discriminatory perceptions of people with disabilities in workplace settings.
